entry.title: Wrap up Melbourne Code Jam 2025
entry.content:
What a fun day of learning it was with guidance from our friends from the SAP Developer Advocate team.

It was refreshing to try and understand about Generative AI and experience it using Python. Thank you to Vitaliy for the excellent session.

Although the turn out could have been better, for those who made it had learnt something very valuable and made some new friends, I know i did. 

After the fun day of learning we hung out with friends from the community advocate team as well at the SAP Stammtisch which was held at The Duke of Wellington

entry.title: SAP Developer News 20th November 2025
entry.content:
ITEMS

Field report from SAP TechEd on Tour in Singapore  

  • SAP Teched home https://www.sap.com/events/teched.html  

CAP â€“ Advanced Event Mesh plugin 

  • @cap-js/advanced-event-mesh plugin https://github.com/cap-js/advanced-event-mesh 
  • CAP Plugin for SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-integration-suite/advanced-event-mesh/cap-plugin-for-sap-integration-suite-advanced-event-mesh 

UKISUG Connect 2025 

  • Event website https://www.ukisugconnect.co.uk/ 
  • Agenda https://virtual.oxfordabstracts.com/event/75555/program  

SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2511 

  • Blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-btp-abap-environment-release-2511/ba-p/14257787 

Devtoberfest 2024 winner interviews at SAP TechEd 2025 â€“ Michael Teti 

  • Devtoberfest details https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest-blog-posts/devtoberfest-2025-welcome/ba-p/14182817  

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro 
0:07 Field report from SAP TechEd on Tour in Singapore 
0:50 CAP â€“ Advanced Event Mesh plugin 
1:21 UKISUG Connect 2025 
2:45 SAP BTP ABAP Environment â€“ Release 2511 
4:00 Devtoberfest 2024 winner interviews at SAP TechEd 2025 â€“ Michael Teti 

TRANSCRIPT

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for November 20th, 2025.

[Tom] Hey, everybody. Welcome from the TechEd on Tour. We're here in Singapore today for a CodeJam, our second to last stop on the TechEd on Tour. Next week, we'll be in Bangalore for the big TechEd event there. Everybody looking forward to that? Yeah. Yeah. Yeah, right now we're here in the SAP offices of Singapore. And if you see behind us, there is Ella, the robotic barista, making Rich a hot chocolate right now. So we're enjoying the comforts of the SAP office and looking forward to seeing everybody in Bangalore next week. So until then, we'll see you there. See you there. Bye. Bye.

[Antonio] Hola, SAP developers. In case you missed it, there is a new CAP plugin in town. the Advanced Event Mesh Plugin. You can leverage this new plugin to easily connect your CAP application with SAP Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh and start publishing or consuming events. Check out the plugin documentation to find out more about how to set up this plugin. I'm including the links in the description. Happy eventing!

[DJ] The conference season is very much in full swing, keeping us developer advocates busy. From organizing and running Devtoberfest through giving the Developer Keynote and running the Developer Garage at TechEd in Berlin and lots more and now many of the team are playing a major role in the On Tour part of the event with a stop in Sydney one in Melbourne and now as you've seen from an earlier item in this very news episode one in Singapore on their way to Bangalore. Over on this side of the world we have coming up the SAP UK and Ireland user group conference Connect. It's a great event it's happening from Sunday the 30th of November through Tuesday the 2nd of December that's right It's like a family reunion lots of discussions take place learning is shared and friendships are made. I'm very honored to be there, I'm running two sessions a hands-on workshop on modeling with CAP's CDS and also a tech talk on local first development with CAP. If you're attending Connect, come along and say hello in fact come to the sessions - the only thing you need to bring is your curiosity. See you there!

[Mamikee] The latest SAP BTP ABAP Environment release 25.11 is here, and it has been available since November 15th. And it's packed with upgrades across ADT, RAP, Fiori, business configuration, integration, and more. So here's a few highlights you don't want to miss. First, big feature drops across the tooling. In ADT, you now get Ghost Text Keyword Completion as the new default. A new editor for email templates. You can create custom email templates using the Maintain Email Template apps and full business configuration set editing right inside ADT. Plus, macOS users, the graphical call timeline for ABAP traces is now supported. In RAP, you can now log base change documents as business events using the new syntax to READ ENTITY, with changes to inspect change operation and define global side effects that refresh UI properties automatically with a single keystroke. Now, this was only a handful of updates. For the full list of updates, read the blog post in the description below.

[Anja & Michael] Welcome here in Berlin TechEd 2025 on site it's so great we handed over from the Devtoberfest now we're here and a lot of TechEd tour stops will join. I'm very happy to have you here, I know that you joined the Devtoberfest and not just joining you did win the Devtoberfest. It's so amazing so what was your experience what did you like, what was your highlight of that? Devtoberfest was incredible. The opportunity to experience the different areas of SAP and to become exposed to those areas was incredible. Having a focus on web technologies, but being exposed to the other services that I was not exposed to prior was very eye-opening and made me a really deep, deep dive into those areas. So I was able to draw some insights that I could reflect back into my work at my work camp. And that's great and now being here on site being on TechEd so what did you ... was thinking or wishing for and what is your highlight here? Oh I was wishing for more and I got more more than that um it was really incredible because it was non -stop sessions um hands-on road mapping um in so many different areas it was uh morning to evening of of of consuming information that I can take back and be empowered with. So I'm very excited to go back and share what I've learned this week. Thank you so much. Thank you.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: SPAIDER Revolucionando Procesos con Inteligencia Artificial
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay #SITCDE2025 nos regalÃ³ una charla fascinante de la mano de Douglas Figueiredo, Socio y CTO de TEIA Connect, @Teia_Connect quien con mÃ¡s de 18 aÃ±os de experiencia en proyectos SAP, nos presentÃ³ SPAIDER: una soluciÃ³n que estÃ¡ revolucionando la manera en que las empresas interactÃºan con sus sistemas mediante inteligencia artificial



Douglas compartiÃ³ una visiÃ³n clara: la inteligencia artificial debe generar valor real en el mundo empresarial. SPAIDER se enfoca en empoderar al usuario final para que ejecute actividades repetitivas y complejas usando simplemente lenguaje natural.

"La persona mÃ¡s importante en el sistema es el usuario final, y necesitamos darle autonomÃ­a para que pueda hacer sus actividades utilizando los motores de inteligencia artificial."

Â¿QuÃ© es SPAIDER?
SPAIDER (SAP Process Artificial Intelligence Evolution Resolution) es un asistente virtual que conecta usuarios con sistemas SAP. El nombre fusiona ingeniosamente Teia (telaraÃ±a en portuguÃ©s) con Spider (araÃ±a en inglÃ©s), representando cÃ³mo esta soluciÃ³n conecta todos los elementos del ecosistema empresarial a travÃ©s de un chat intuitivo.


Los Cuatro Pilares de SPAIDER
SPAIDER-eDOCS: Gestiona automÃ¡ticamente documentos fiscales electrÃ³nicos, emitiendo mÃ¡s de 30 tipos de documentos obligatorios, consultando XMLs y optimizando aprobaciones gubernamentales.
SPAIDER-MONI: Monitoreo inteligente que supervisa aspectos tÃ©cnicos y de negocio, alertando proactivamente sobre problemas antes de que impacten las operaciones.
SPAIDER-ESPEC: Genera especificaciones funcionales y prototipos mediante conversaciÃ³n natural, permitiendo que cualquier usuario documente requisitos sin conocimientos tÃ©cnicos.
SPAIDER-TEST: Automatiza pruebas de regresiÃ³n, ejecutando procesos completos y comparando valores con precisiÃ³n del 100%. Genera evidencias en PDF para validaciÃ³n de cambios.



Durante la presentaciÃ³n, Douglas mostrÃ³ el poder del lenguaje natural con SPAIDER-TEST. Con un simple comando como "crear un pedido de venta normal", el sistema identifica el tipo de pedido, consulta la referencia, crea automÃ¡ticamente todo el proceso (pedido, entrega, factura) y presenta los resultados de forma clara.
Cuando modificÃ³ intencionalmente un dato de material para simular un impacto fiscal, SPAIDER-TEST detectÃ³ automÃ¡ticamente las diferencias, las cuantificÃ³ con precisiÃ³n y generÃ³ un reporte comparativo. Todo esto sin escribir cÃ³digo ni navegar por mÃºltiples transacciones SAP.


La VisiÃ³n de Teia Connect
Lo mÃ¡s inspirador fue entender la filosofÃ­a de Teia Connect sobre IA: no reemplazar personas, sino empoderarlas. En Teia, todos utilizan IA diariamente, los candidatos deben demostrar cÃ³mo la usan, y cada producto se construye con esta tecnologÃ­a. Como Douglas enfatizÃ³: "La integraciÃ³n debe ser transparente para el usuario, sin necesidad de mirar mÃºltiples transacciones."
El Mensaje Final
SPAIDER representa un cambio fundamental en la interacciÃ³n con sistemas empresariales: democratizar el acceso para que cualquier usuario ejecute procesos complejos, liberar tiempo estratÃ©gico automatizando tareas repetitivas, y generar valor real usando IA para resolver problemas concretos de negocio.
Â¿Lo mejor? SPAIDER es modular y escalable, adaptÃ¡ndose a las necesidades especÃ­ficas de cada empresa.

Un especial agradecimiento a Douglas Figueiredo por compartir su conocimiento y pasiÃ³n por la innovaciÃ³n, demostrando cÃ³mo la inteligencia artificial puede transformar realmente los procesos empresariales. A Teia Connect por desarrollar soluciones que empoderan a los usuarios y generan valor tangible en el ecosistema SAP.

Gracias tambiÃ©n al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay por hacer posible estos espacios de aprendizaje que fortalecen nuestra comunidad y nos mantienen a la vanguardia de la tecnologÃ­a.

entry.title: Blog it Forward - Mino Kato
entry.content:
(The Japanese version follows the English text.) â€»æ—¥æœ¬èªç‰ˆã¯è‹±èªã®ã‚ã¨ã«ç¶šãã¾ã™ã€‚

Introduction

Hello everyone! I received the "Blog it Forward" baton from @sumikko , who organizes community with me, and I am writing this post now. Thank you, Sumikko-san, for this great opportunity! You can read Sumikko-san's post [here] and learn more about the BIF challenge [here].

About Me

My name is Mino Kato. Since "Mino" is a rare name in Japan, people usually call me by my first name rather than a nickname.

I have been working as an SAP consultant in the accounting area for many years. Recently, I have been focusing on projects involving S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (now SAP Cloud ERP), specifically sticking to the "Fit to Standard" approach. I am also an organizer for chillSAP, a local SAP community in Japan, along with Sumikko-san.

Although I am not a developer myself, I love catching up on BTP extension-related and AI-related knowledge that helps users utilize the system more conveniently. This passion motivates my community activities and my multiple participations in SAP TechEd.

My Encounter with SAP

I joined an IT company as a new graduate. After training, the first project I was assigned to along with several colleagues was already in trouble, and we were thrown in as testing personnel. While the business trips and the relationships with the people I worked with are good memories, I suddenly experienced the difficulty of building a system from scratch (or rather, the chaos involving many people when things go wrong).

So, when that project ended and I was given the choice, "Do you want to be involved in Web development or ERP projects next?", I chose ERP without hesitation and went to receive SAP training.

When I saw the SAP system screen (GUI at the time) for the first time, my impression was: "Wow! The buttons are so detailed, and their shapes are perfectly aligned!"

It might sound funny now, but after seeing the chaos, I was moved by the order. Of course, I now know that ERP projects are also difficult and have their own challenges...

Participating in SAP TechEd

Under the mission of "Let's catch up on SAP's new technologies and think of new services" at the company I belonged to at the time, I participated in SAP TechEd for the first time in 2018. I had participated in SAP Inside Track Tokyo in Japan before and felt that TechEd would be interesting. Actually participating, I was able to feel the passion of global engineers and participants from Japan. I thought, "Ah, I love places where we can have these kinds of conversations," which became the trigger for me to actively involve myself in community activities.

Photo from a past TechEd FunRun. I loved these kinds of events too!

Encounter with the Community

During the "Japan Night" at TechEd, I was scouted to speak at SAP Inside Track Tokyo, and presenting on the theme of Design Thinking was a very good experience. I originally loved listening to other people's presentations, but participating as a speaker was an experience that broke down a wall for me. Since that presentation, I think I have become able to jump into various places with lighter footwork.

Long ago, when I started touching SAP, if I ran into something I didn't understand in the finance module, I could only ask seniors at my company or guess the mechanism from SAP Notes information. But now, compared to before, help documents and KBAs are substantial, and we can gain various insights through QA or Blogs in the global community.

And furthermore, it is very stimulating and happy if I can read it in Japanese... Based on such motivation, the SAP Advent Calendar, LT (Lightning Talk) event, and various events of the community "chillSAP" started.

My Favorite Things (Fun Facts)

I love going to the theater. My eyes are glued to living humans unfolding action such as dancing and sword fighting right in front of me. I go to watch ballet, musicals, popular theater, and "2.5-dimensional" plays quite often recently. The opera I watched in between TechEd Berlin the other day was also wonderful. After the pandemic, my spirit of "Let's watch what I want to see live while I can!" has spurred on. I get energy from the stage and turn it into vitality for my daily life.

Sitting in a chair for a long time for theatergoing is bad for the body, but I think doing Yoga regularly helps with that. I like "Ashtanga Yoga," which is quite hard for yoga.

Photo with my teacher Cathy from Hawaii, who I took online classes with during the pandemic, when she came to Japan. (For some reason, she took photos in 3 patterns: vertical, horizontal, and diagonal. This is the diagonal version!)

Answers to BIF Questions

1. If you were 20 again, what would you study?

I might try to get a degree in accounting and get closer to a CPA qualification. In promoting "Fit to Standard," I sometimes feel that having a qualification is easy to understand to be recognized as a specialist in the accounting area. However, learning it after becoming a working adult competes with too many other things I want to learn (English, other foreign languages, SAP and AI technology catch-up), so... But I have no regrets about proceeding to the path of IT by becoming interested in computers while doing experiments and programming in the science department. If I had proceeded to the path of accounting, there is a high possibility that I would not be doing my current job, so I feel it is asking for the moon after all. I will continue to study accounting within the range I can now.

2. What is the most important thing you learned from your parents?

Rather than "learned," it is what they "gave" me. They gave me many books since I was a child, and perhaps due to my original preference, I grew up to be a book lover, which I think is my asset now. I loved experiencing different worlds through picture books and children's books. As I grew up, I read many books including manga, and I was able to know various ways of life and ways of thinking. Being a book lover is also useful when learning new technologies and knowledge now. I love the feeling of my world expanding.

Closing

Thank you for reading this far. Next, I would like to pass the baton to @MikuKawanabe. She is running JSUG's Next Gen Boost community, and I am always stimulated by her powerful activities! I definitely want to know the secret of that energy.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: One step after the other - Long-distance hiking
entry.content:
From one extreme hobby to another: While rileyrainey enjoys jumping down from huge heights, I love hiking the extra mile. Or better said: hiking over thousands of kilometers, one day after another, one step at a time. I am happy to take on the baton in the SAP  Community Hobbies series and introduce my passion of long-distance hiking to you. 

Who I am?

Hi! I am Jan Rumig from Germany, a Chief Development Architect in the SAP Business Technology Platform. As a contrast to my daily office hours, I spend most of my leisure time with hiking, reading about hiking and taking pictures of our beautiful nature while hiking. One could say I breathe hiking. Since recently, I also found passion in standing in front of big audiences and talk about my adventures.

How my love for hiking began

I wasnâ€™t even born yet when my parents first took me to the mountains. It all began back then in Ramsau am Dachstein, where I spent several weeks each year with my family. During my teenage years, I went on my first solo hikes there. Later, as a young adult, I started to intensify this passion - spending one or two weeks a year in mountain regions, always with a fixed base. At that time, I already had the desire to explore new and more distant regions, but often I lacked hiking companions, and I didnâ€™t quite have the courage to set out on my own.

First Solo Adventures: Portugal, the Balkans, and Beyond

Everything changed after a painful breakup. From that moment on, there was no holding back. My first solo hike took me to the Rota Vicentina, the Fishermenâ€™s Trail in Portugal - one of the most beautiful coastal hikes in the world. Many more regions followed: Serbia, Romania, Ukraine, the Peaks of the Balkans Trail, Colombia, and several others. I was infected with hiking fever. The more I saw and experienced, the more I wanted to discover. Between trips to faraway countries, I explored the Alps. And even on weekends, I felt the urge to head outdoors. Luckily, I live close to wonderful hiking regions - the Odenwald, the Palatinate, or the Black Forest are my weekly playgrounds.

ğŸ§Some details of the Peaks of the Balkans, I discussed in a podcast, in German only: Wanderwach & Kaffee.

Beautiful coastline on the Rota Vicentina

Gjeravica, highest mountain of Cosovo

Inspiration from New Zealand: Te Araroa

But deep down, I had always carried an unfulfilled desire to experience a truly long and demanding adventure. At first, my own inner doubts held me back: You wonâ€™t manage this, something could happen to youâ€¦ You can still do such an adventure at a later point in time. Then, in 2022, two colleagues of mine passed away unexpectedly. It was a harsh reminder not to postpone life. I asked my boss whether I could take six months off. Luckily, I had accumulated 162 vacation days over the years. My leave was approved. Some years earlier, I had heard of the Te Araroa in New Zealand - 3,000 km through breathtaking landscapes. So, over the turn of the year 2023/2024, I set off for New Zealand. The Te Araroa is considered one of the toughest long-distance trails in the world - and for good reason. While it is fully marked, it often leads through pathless terrain. In total, I had to ford around 100 rivers, some of them chest-deep. Much of the forest felt like jungle, and the â€œtrailâ€ was often nothing more than a mudfest. Yet, perhaps because of these challenges, it became an unforgettable experience that profoundly changed me and my outlook on life. And â€œunfortunately,â€ it also sparked an insatiable appetite for long-distance hiking and adventure. I decided then and there to take more extended breaks in the future, balancing my career with my passion for the outdoors.

ğŸ§Podcast epiode about all the details of my hike through New Zealand, in German only: Holy Sheep Neuseeland. 

Typical New Zealand forestSunrise over the Richmond RangesJan above Lake ConstanceRainbow over mountain hutEnd of Te Araroa trail in Bluff

Discovering my homeland

No sooner had one adventure ended than I wanted to plan the next. But after those long-haul flights to New Zealand, I didnâ€™t want to put such a strain on the environment again. Thatâ€™s when everything came together: during my trek in New Zealand, I listened to a podcast where Soulboy spoke about the creation of the North South Trail (NST). From that moment, a seed was planted: Wouldnâ€™t it be wonderful to explore my own homeland on foot? Many of the trails that make up the NST had already been on my personal wish list for some time. And while on the Te Araroa I was just one of about 4,000 hikers per year, only around 30 verified hikers had completed the NST in its entirety so far. So, my decision was clear: in 2025, I would set out to hike the NST.
What were my expectations for the trail? I was well aware that the wilderness experience of New Zealand couldnâ€™t be replicated in Germany - and I wasnâ€™t looking for that. Instead, I wanted to get to know my homeland step by step, meter by meter, discovering its many facets from north to south. A few examples: the landscape begins flat as a pancake in the north and gradually grows more mountainous as you move south. Or take food: up north itâ€™s MettbrÃ¶tchen for breakfast or giant Rumkugeln from the bakery, in the Palatinate itâ€™s Saumagen, and in the south youâ€™re rewarded with Kaiserschmarrn. And I was eager to explore regions Iâ€™d never visited before, many of which had long been on my list. On its 3,700 kilometers, the North South Trail connects 36 certified trails leading through 30 national parks.
People often ask me which parts of the North South Trail were my favorites. Uff, thatâ€™s a tough question. Every region has something exciting to offer, and I honestly canâ€™t narrow it down to just one. The Saar-HunsrÃ¼ck-Steig fascinated me because itâ€™s so diverse and offers a little bit of everything: narrow singletracks, streams, beautiful forests, castles, and more. The Palatinate Wine Trail felt special because itâ€™s close to my home, so I felt a sense of familiarity there - and the Palatinate people are simply warm-hearted folks. Even in the Black Forest, where I had plenty of bad weather, there were memorable sections - especially the famous Schluchtensteig. But if I had to pick what touched me the most, itâ€™s always the high mountains. Thatâ€™s why the Nagelfluhkette near the end of the trail truly stole my heart.

ğŸ§Some stories and more details of my walk through Germany can be found in this podcast episode, in German only: Off the Path.

Deer under treesRed KitePalatinate forestMountain in cloudsJan above Oberstdorf valleyMost southern point of Germany: Haldenwanger Eck

 

What is so fascinating in long-distance hiking

As I indicated already before, I love being outdoors, experiencing all sensory impulses from nature and watching and photographing all the beauty out there. But these reasons are not specific to long-distance hiking. What makes long distances special: you have to carry all your stuff on your back, most of the times including a tent and cooking equipment. On my hike through Germany I carried a total weight of around 18 kg without water. While hiking, you reduce yourself to the most minimal needs. As a famous female German hiker, Christine ThÃ¼rmer, says: every day you only focus on walk, sleep, eat, repeat. If you then get a shower after several days or you buy a chocolate bar, these small things make you really, really happy.

ğŸ§ More details about the fascination of long-distance hiking, I discussed in a podcast episode, in German only: Frei Raus. 

All my stuff for a long distance hike

Special support: Trail Angels ğŸ‘¼

Have you ever heard about trail angels? For long-distance hikers these are true angels. These are usually private individuals that support hikers along the trail with free food or a chance for an overnight sleeping opportunity. On my trip through Germany, I stayed at 25 trail angels. Most of these stays were much better than any hotel. Sometimes there was a delicious dinner, a free bed and a rich breakfast. As most of them are also outdoorsy, I got new inspirations for future adventures. These encounters with foreign people is exactly what's missing in today's world: love towards humans that you don't know.

Reaching the final signpost

Although I enjoy every minute of my walks, it is such a wonderful feeling when you reach the final signpost at the end of your long trail. All the tension falls apart and you feel deeply relieved. I am always really proud of what I achieved with my body. Our body is the most fascinating thing. Once accommodated, it carries you everywhere like a machine. We have to cherish all of it and take care about our health. My proudest moment so far was achieving the North South Trail in Fastest known time. For the 3,700 km I only needed 96 hiking days + 2 rest days.

Everybody can do it

You have doubts if you can do the same? Don't worry. The good news is: you can. Before you start on a long hike, do some test hikes. First maybe start with a single days, then a weekender, followed by multiple days. If you feel comfortable, go for something longer. And when the day comes, the important thing is, start slowly and give your body the time it needs to accommodate to the efforts. Day by day you will feel getting stronger and more endurable. The worst thing you can do is to never start. Always remember that our life is limited. Better regret the things you've done than the things you haven't done. 

What will be next?

So, am I done with long-distance hiking now? Absolutely not - quite the opposite. The big question is simply: whatâ€™s next? For now, I think Iâ€™ll choose something a little shorter. Current favorites include the High Scardus Trail through North Macedonia, Kosovo, and Albania, the Lycian Way in Turkey, or perhaps the GR20 on Corsica as an add-on. But who knows - maybe something entirely different will come my way.
Besides hiking, I discovered another related hobby: talking about my adventures. So I take my pictures and videos, convert them into visually attractive multi-vision shows, add stories and present them in front of big audiences. Let's connect if you see a chance for me to present my adventures somewhere close by to you. ğŸ˜Š

ğŸŸ  For readers based in Germany around Heidelberg, there is the perfect opportunity to listen first-hand about my hike through New Zealand, I will be a speaker at the wonderful Wunderwelten Festival on January 3rd.  

One of my talks about the hike through New Zealand

 

Want to know more?

You also want to start hiking? There are a lot of outdoor portals where you can easily find beautiful hikes around the place where you live. Just search for tours in your region in your favorite search engine. Additionally, contact me, I might have some proposals. ğŸ˜‡

You became curious to learn more about my hikes?

  • You find a lot of pictures and daily reports of my travels on my Instagram account. 
  • You can access all my hikes on Komoot.

Coming up next

I am happy to pass the baton to Marika who is introducing her hobbies singing and theatre to us. In addition she engages in meaningful volunteer work. Stay tuned!

entry.content:

SAP Business Technology Platform: Conectar e Innovar

Las empresas buscan agilidad e innovaciÃ³n para competir, transformarse y prosperar:

Las Tres Ãreas de SAP BTP
1. App Dev & Automation
Experiencia low-code/no-code y herramientas pro-code
AutomatizaciÃ³n robÃ³tica de procesos
GestiÃ³n del flujo de trabajo

Productos de datos listos para la empresa
Toma de decisiones aumentada por IA
Plataforma de datos abiertos

3. Integration
3,800+ integraciones preconstruidas
4,400+ APIs y grÃ¡ficos de datos
IntegraciÃ³n de procesos E2E para soluciones SAP y no-SAP

Como mencionÃ³ Juan Pablo: "Estos proyectos de BTP son altamente muy rÃ¡pidos, son proyectos cortos de dos, tres meses y las empresas necesitan esos cambios inmediatos."

SAP Build: La SoluciÃ³n Unificada
SAP Build Apps

  • Funciones visuales en la nube para aplicaciones de pila completa
  • Desarrollo colaborativo entre negocio y desarrolladores
  • Soporte multicanal para mÃ³viles y web
  • IntegraciÃ³n vÃ­a API REST y OData

SAP Build Process Automation

  • Flujos de trabajo con arrastrar y soltar
  • Soluciones prediseÃ±adas
  • IA incorporada para generaciÃ³n de procesos

Durante la presentaciÃ³n mostrÃ³ un ejemplo de Purchase Requisition Approval, donde Joule ayuda a generar el requisition y crea automÃ¡ticamente el flujo de trabajo completo.

Joule Studio
Permite crear agentes de IA personalizados:

  • Comprenden y resuelven problemas comerciales especÃ­ficos
  • Experiencia conversacional unificada
  • Seguridad integrada de nivel empresarial

Â¿Por DÃ³nde Empezar?
Juan Pablo compartiÃ³ recursos clave:

  • SAP BTP Guidance Framework: GuÃ­as de decisiÃ³n, arquitecturas de referencia y mejores prÃ¡cticas
  • SAP Discovery Center: Casos de uso, historias de clientes y estimador de costos
  • SAP Learning: MÃ¡s de 100 SAP Learning Journeys gratuitos
  • Free Tier and Trial: Probar SAP BTP sin costo inicial

"BTP se puede usar muchÃ­simo... todo esto se puede tambiÃ©n utilizar con una cuenta free trial. No te requiere hardware, lo Ãºnico que vas a tener que instalar es un cloud connector."

Estrategias de MigraciÃ³n a SAP S/4HANA
Brownfield vs Greenfield
Brownfield (ConversiÃ³n de Sistema)

  • ConversiÃ³n tÃ©cnica completa de SAP ERP existente a S/4HANA
  • Utilizar tecnologÃ­a e instalaciones existentes
  • Comenzar rÃ¡pidamente
  • Menor riesgo

Greenfield (Nueva ImplementaciÃ³n)

  • ReingenierÃ­a y simplificaciÃ³n de procesos
  • Elegir nueva tecnologÃ­a
  • Realizar carga de datos inicial
  • Mayor planificaciÃ³n inicial

SAP Readiness Check: El Punto de Partida
Juan Pablo explicÃ³ que esta herramienta indica quÃ© tan preparado estÃ¡ el sistema para migrar a S/4HANA, analizando:

  • Compatibilidad tÃ©cnica (versiÃ³n, add-ons, extensiones)
  • CÃ³digo ABAP y funciones obsoletas
  • Rendimiento y dimensionamiento
  • Procesos de negocio y oportunidades de mejora
  • Recomendaciones Fiori

"Se hace siempre previo a hacer las conversiones para tener una hoja de ruta real de cÃ³mo estamos parados hoy dÃ­a del sistema y todos los ajustes que hay que hacer."

SAP Simplification Check
Muestra quÃ© cambios concretos hacer en procesos, datos y funciones:
VerificaciÃ³n de Relevancia

Identifica quÃ© Simplification Items aplican
Dimensiona el impacto funcional y tÃ©cnico

VerificaciÃ³n de Consistencia

  • Comprueba que datos y procesos cumplan las nuevas estructuras
  • Detecta inconsistencias antes de la conversiÃ³n

ConversiÃ³n de Sistema: Fases Principales
Fase de PreparaciÃ³n:

  • Requerimientos del sistema
  • Maintenance Planner
  • Pre checks
  • Custom code preparation
  • Unicode conversion, OS & DB Version, SPAM Version

Fase de RealizaciÃ³n:

  • SUM (Software Update Manager)
  • MigraciÃ³n DB
  • Software Update
  • Data Conversion

"Es importantÃ­simo actualizar la SPAM. Es muy importantÃ­simo porque las empresas vienen de sistemas viejos y tenemos que validar las versiones compatibles de base de datos y sistema operativo."

El DesafÃ­o del CÃ³digo Custom
Juan Pablo fue claro sobre el mayor desafÃ­o:
"La tarea mÃ¡s ardua es todos los reportes que vamos a ver... la idea de SAP en la conversiÃ³n es limpiar y tratar de minimizar al mÃ­nimo el tema de los desarrollos."
"Hay que analizar si esas aplicaciones llevarlas a cÃ³digo en BTP o directamente reemplazarla. Porque en muchos casos hay esa funcionalidad, alguien desarrollÃ³ algo y hoy dÃ­a estÃ¡ disponible en las aplicaciones estÃ¡ndar."


Agradecemos a Kuaa technology por su patrocinio del SAP Inside Track Paraguay SITCDE2025, haciendo posible estos espacios de aprendizaje en la comunidad SAP.
Un agradecimiento especial a Juan Pablo Barril por compartir su conocimiento tÃ©cnico sobre SAP BTP y las estrategias de migraciÃ³n a S/4HANA de manera clara y prÃ¡ctica.
Â¡Gracias al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay!

entry.title: SAP Q4 first meetup highlights
entry.content:
This is the last quarter of the year 2025. We organized another SAP event for the Columbus location. This event became special because of two things. First, a few new members joined the event online on Google Meet, and second, we plan to organize SAP Inside Track at the Columbus location. New members who joined the event for the first time are Pavan Sarda, Sumit Maloo and Vishal Gupta. They all introduced themselves, their experience, type of industry experience etc.

 

We got very good inputs for organizing the SAP Inside Track. Suggestions were given to organize the following events: speaker, workshops, tea, and lunch. Topics can be related to the latest innovations in SAP S4HANA, industry-specific knowledge, Role of artificial intelligence in industry. Workshops can be conducted on introducing SAP S4HANA knowledge in the education system.

The next plan of action will be to contact SAP Germany and share the plan and arrange the approval to organize the event.

entry.title: When Physical Identity Turns Digital: Rethinking Traceability in Enterprise Integration
entry.content:
Modern large scale integration architectures are powered by advance resurgence of observability, distributed tracing, and correlations.
The advancement in observability and analytics platform, provides confidence to extend the reach of integration and envision more on horizon.

The traceability improvement is not limited to the digital world.
The evolutionary spiral is expanding in the realms of supply chain operations, infobahn and data reservoirs.

With EPCIS(Electronic Product Code Information Services) upgrade to version 2.0, the business events, propagating downstream, upstream or in the reverse logistic channel- can be wrapped in json-ld/json file and can be upserted at each stage of the supply chain to the next.

Key EPC identifiers are GTIN, SGTIN(Combination of serial number and GTIN), GRAI(Global Returnable Asset Identifier) and SSCC(Serial Shipping Container Code).

The core idea of this blog is to use the physical EPC(Electronic Product Code) identifiers as W3C trace context identifiers such as traceparent and tracestate.
Each integrated (and OTEL observable) cloud/web application , in case forwards, these identifiers from one system to other, as part of HTTP headers then the organizations can establish strong correlation between physical supply chain events and digital system interactions. A major leverage point of these headers, would be the scenarios, where asynchronous request and response is used at larger scale for e.g. usage of SAP Event Mesh, JMS Queues etc.

For supply-chain leaders and digital-transformation executives, the multi-fold benefits are clear:
a unified, correlated view of physical events and digital flows, enabling deeper insights, quicker decisions, and more successful operations. From a different vantage point, the digital trails set by W3C trace context, reflects the recording of physical events by the digital systems as traceparent/tracestate, whenever the system digitally observes a product related event(specified by EPCIS jason-ld file) passing through it.

Following are few methods to set/derive the W3C trace context using epc ids:
- Set traceparent as hash of epc id.
- Set tracestate as epc id.
- Set trace-id field of traceparent as epc id(if epc id is a UUID).

Below you would find an http client snippet which performs the above suggested steps.  The snippet below is only for didactic purpose.

with open("epcis_payload.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
    payload = json.load(file)

#epcis file itself can carry traceparent as part of extension field; if present extract and set it 
traceParent = None
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceparent' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceParent = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceparent']

#Otherwise, hash the epc id and set traceparent with the obtained value post hashing             
if traceParent == None:            
    # Create deterministic 16 byte trace ID
    if 'epcList' in payload:
        traceId = hashlib.sha256(str(payload['epcList']).encode()).hexdigest()[:32]
    else:
        traceId = str(uuid.uuid4())[:32]
    span_uuid = uuid.uuid4()
    spanId = str(span_uuid)
    #traceparent = 00-<trace-id>-<span-id>-01
    traceParent = '00-' + traceId + '-' + spanId[:16] + '-01'

#Add traceparent as http header 
headers.update({"traceparent": traceParent})

#epcis file itself can carry tracestate as part of extension field; if present extract and set it
traceState = ""
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceState' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceState = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceState']

#Otherwise, set the tracestate as epc id           
if traceState == "":
        if 'epcList' in payload: 
            # Create tracestate from EPCIS Id
            traceState = 'epcList = ' + str(payload['epcList'])
        if 'inputEPCList' in payload:
            # Extend the tracestate
            if 'epcList' in traceState:
                traceState = traceState + ',' + 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
            else:
                traceState = 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
        if 'outputEPCList' in payload:
            traceState = traceState + ',' + 'outputEPCList = ' + str(payload['outputEPCList'])

#Add tracestate as http header 
headers.update({"tracestate": traceState})

#POST request
response = requests.post(url, auth=HTTPBasicAuth(username, password), headers=headers, json=payload)

The EPCIS json-ld/json file forwarder, can even send traceparent and tracestate(as part of extension field of the file) along with business event details.

In the Runtime Configuration of Integration Flow, set traceparent and tracestate as allowed headers (as shown below):

One can even think of embedding the returned MPL ID (from SAP Integration Suite. as part of HTTP response), into tracestate for further transmission down the lane. Later, the predecessor MPL IDs and Integration Flows involved, in processing, the EPCIS json-Ld, can be determined as per explanation in following help documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/using-ids-to-filter-messages?locale=en-US&q=predecessor

An EPCIS event describes what, where, why, when and how about the business event. Taking an abstract look to overall above suggested scheme-  it would appear as if a new dimension is added to EPCIS event i.e. who(digitally viewed the event).


Now imagine that the integrated systems are streaming these message headers to data lake such as SAP Business Data Cloud or to a data federation system. This would then open a new portal to the world of federated tracing and large scale correlation. By indexing with traceparent, the correlated messages, in data lake and federation system, can be brought together.

Additionally, the W3C trace context headers can be stored as custom header properties, in message processing logs, in SAP Integration Suite. These settings can be achieved by (AI assisted) groovy scripting in SAP Integration Suite.

Below snippet reflects the extraction of traceparent and tracestate from the http header and setting the same as MPL's custom headers.

def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(attachmentName, body, "text/plain")
    } 
    def traceid = message.getHeader("traceparent", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("traceparent", traceid)
    
    def tracestate = message.getHeader("tracestate", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("tracestate", tracestate)

One can then view these custom headers, in Message Monitor section of SAP Integration Suite, as shown below:

 

The added custom attributes would be then visible, in SAP Cloud ALM as well, provided the respective SAP Integration Suite and  SAP Cloud ALM tenants are already dovetailed.

Harvest above insights and ideas and redefine the observability of supply chains !


References:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/message-processing-log-text-view?locale=en-US
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/raw-data-inbound-logs?locale=en-US

entry.title: Recap SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025: A Celebration of Community, Innovation, and Shared Knowledge.
What a journey it's been! Last November 14th, we wrapped up the 9th edition of SAP Inside Track Barcelona, and I'm still buzzing from the energy, connections, and incredible moments we shared together.

More Than Just an Event

There's something truly special about SAP Inside Track. Yes, it's about SAP technologies, innovation, and learning â€” but at its core, it's about people. It's about creating a space where developers, consultants, architects, and SAP enthusiasts can come together, share their experiences, and build genuine connections that go beyond the professional realm.
This year, we brought together +100 passionate individuals in a historic Modernist building in the heart of Barcelona. From the moment the doors opened until the last photo was taken the spirit of community was palpable.


Knowledge That Inspires

The quality of sessions this year was outstanding. Our speakers delivered thought-provoking presentations covering the full spectrum of SAP technologies:

  • AI and Innovation: From Vision AI applications in quality management to conversational AI solutions that let you "talk" to your data
  • SAP BTP: Deep dives into the Business Technology Platform and its transformative capabilities of SAP Hana with Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph
  • Next-Generation Talent: Insights into how SAP University Alliances is empowering the future of our ecosystem
  • SAP BTP Real-World Solutions: Practical implementations of SAP Integration Suite, CAP, FIORI, Printing solution, Identity Services, sand more
  • Freelance market barometer 2025

A special highlight was the Spanish final of the AUSIA Hackathon -  AUSAPE final,  where we witnessed incredible creativity and problem-solving. Congratulations to SDG Group for their winning solution combining AI, data modeling, and planning on SAP BTP, and to Brait Partners for their innovative electronic invoicing automation platform. Both teams proved that new technologies have real, tangible applications in today's business landscape.

The Power of Community: A New Milestone

Speaking of community strength, I'm thrilled to share some exciting news that perfectly exemplifies what we've built together: three new extraordinary members from our community have just joined the SAP Champions program! This recognition is a testament to the collaborative spirit, knowledge sharing, and genuine passion that defines our Barcelona and Spain SAP ecosystem. It's proof that when we come together, support each other, and actively contribute to the community, incredible things happen. These achievements don't belong to individuals alone â€” they're a reflection of the nurturing environment we've created through events like SIT Barcelona. Congratulations to our new Champions; you make us all proud! ğŸ† @AAncos @DanielMateo @Lluis 


Gratitude to Those Who Made It Possible

None of this would have been possible without our amazing volunteering speakers who shared their expertise, experiences, and passion. Your willingness to prepare, present, and engage with attendees is what makes SIT Barcelona such a valuable learning experience. Thank you for your time, your knowledge, and your commitment to our community.
To our sponsors â€” thank you for believing in the power of community events. Your support enables us to create these spaces where innovation flourishes and connections are made. You're not just supporting an event; you're investing in the growth and development of the SAP ecosystem in Spain.

And I must give a huge, heartfelt thank you to the entire SIT Barcelona organizing team, LluÃ­s, Mireia, Enric, Losel, Imma and Saul. Your dedication, countless hours of planning, problem-solving on the fly, and unwavering passion made this 9th edition possible. You are the backbone of this community, and working alongside each of you has been an absolute privilegeğŸ’™

The Heart of It All: Community

What sets SAP Inside Track apart from other tech events is the genuine sense of community we've built together over these nine years. It's in the coffee conversations, the spontaneous debates about architecture patterns, the exchange of LinkedIn profiles, and yes, even in the collective patience when life happens (like dog medication time!).
I've seen friendships form, collaborations spark, and careers transform through the connections made at SIT Barcelona. Whether you're a first-time attendee or a veteran of all nine editions, everyone is welcomed with open arms into this wonderful ecosystem we've created together.

Looking Ahead

As we celebrate the success of our 9th edition, we're already excited about what's to come. The 10th anniversary of SIT Barcelona is on the horizon, and we have a feeling it's going to be something truly special.
To everyone who attended, spoke, sponsored, organized, or simply spread the word â€” thank you. You are the reason SAP Inside Track Barcelona exists and thrives. You are the community.
Until next year, keep innovating, keep sharing, and keep being awesome! ğŸš€

P.S. â€” If you missed this edition or want to be part of this amazing community, stay tuned for announcements about SIT Barcelona 2026. Trust me, you don't want to miss the 10th anniversary!
#SITBarcelona #SAPInsideTrack #SAPCommunity #SAP #SAPBTP #SAPDevelopers #CommunityEvents #BarcelonaTech #TechCommunity

  • PDFã¯è‹±èªã§ã™ãŒã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ãƒ–ãƒƒã‚¯å½¢å¼ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã¯ç¿»è¨³æ‰‹æ®µã¯ä½•ã¨ã§ã‚‚ãªã‚‹ã®ã§ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒ«ã«ã¯ãªã‚‰ãªã„ã‹ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

entry.title: How I Escaped Browser Tab Hell: A Lesson in Choosing the Right AI Tool
entry.content:
The Journey

The Problem: 10 Years of Digital Hoarding

After a decade at SAP, I was drowning in resources. My solution? Browser bookmarks that grew into an unmanageable mess. When Chrome introduced Tab Groups, I thought I'd found salvationâ€”until I realized I was maintaining 200+ tabs across multiple groups. The anxiety from my digital FOMO was worse than ever.

Back to Basics (With a Twist)

I returned to curated bookmarks but with a new goal: create a "PM Toolbox" that I could easily maintain and share with colleagues across the organization. I built a clean bookmark folder and mirrored it on a wiki page.

The Maintenance Nightmare

Within weeks, reality hit: my bookmark folder evolved constantly, requiring manual wiki updates. Chrome's bookmark export format (the ancient Netscape standard) made extracting subsets error-prone and frustrating. I needed automation.

First Attempt: GenAI Fails the Coding Test

I tried using Claude 4.5 Sonnet through GenAI-XL. Despite multiple attempts, it couldn't handle Chrome's non-standard HTML format. It kept reaching for HTML parsing libraries that failed, then suggested an obscure Netscape parser that violated SAP standards. Dead end.

Second Attempt: GitHub Copilot Nails It

The next day, I switched to VSCode with GitHub Copilot. Here's what changed:
  1. I wrote clear requirements in a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file, specifically calling out the Netscape format complexity
  2. Copilot enhanced my requirements, suggesting testing coverage and documentation guidelines (80% of the final instructions came from Copilot)
  3. I switched to Agent mode and prompted: "Please create the missing files. Do not reference public code in your response." (Critical for enterprise compliance)
The result? A complete, working scriptâ€”instantly.

But it got better. When I asked for a second script to generate Confluence tables, Copilot:
  • Created the implementation
  • Built the test suite when I requested it
  • Ran the tests autonomously, discovered bugs, and fixed themâ€”all without me asking
I was genuinely amazed.

Key Takeaways

1. Match the Tool to the Task

  • General AI (like Claude): Excellent for brainstorming, requirements refinement, and PM tasks
  • Specialized coding AI (like GitHub Copilot): Purpose-built for implementation and testing

2. Clear Requirements Are Non-Negotiable

Both attempts used AI, but only the second succeeded because I provided structured, detailed requirements upfront.

3. Embrace Test-Driven Development

Even with AI assistance, automated testing is essential. Copilot's self-correction only worked because tests exposed the bugs immediately.

4. Simple Solutions Often Win

Sometimes the answer isn't a shinier toolâ€”it's going back to basics (curated bookmarks) with smart automation layered on top.

The Bottom Line

AI coding assistants aren't magicâ€”they're power tools. Like any tool, they require the right context, clear instructions, and quality controls. When you provide those, the results can be transformative.

For PMs and non-developers: you don't need to be a coder to automate your work. You just need to understand your requirements so you can clearly write them down and choose the AI tool designed for the job.

References

You can find the scripts in question here

Los eventos SAP Inside Track son espacios Ãºnicos donde la comunidad SAP cobra vida:

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP TechEd on Tour brought the best out of Berlin, Bengaluru, and Sydney!
entry.content:
As SAP TechEd on Tour continues to inspire people around the world, our SAP community is buzzing with fresh insights, great lessons, and standout contributions from Developer Advocates, SAP Champions and Mentors, and members from local groups. This edition of our newsletter brings you some of the blog posts that dive deeper into the most talked-about topics from SAP TechEd in Berlin, Bengaluru and Sydney. Whether you joined the events in person or are catching up virtually, these resources will help you to keep the innovation energy high and inspired to thrive on the SAP topics. 

Beyond technical content, weâ€™re also spotlighting the vibrant connections forming at the SAP Community in-person gatherings. From post-sessions reflections to personal stories, these posts reflect the passion and collaboration that make our community grow. Weâ€™re excited to share not only the knowledge but also the experiences and inspiration that emerged through the month of November. So, dive in and keep the momentum going! 

Featured Blog Posts 

Follow-up of the â€œBest of UI5â€œ demo presented at SAP TechEd in Bengaluru 

One of the highlights of SAP TechEd on Tour was the amazing demos presented by our Community Advocates and Developer Advocates. At the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru last week, Nico Schoenteich demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements. As a follow-up to his demo presented at the Developer Keynote, he published a blog post about how to consume arbitrary web components natively in UI5 applications. Whether you were on-site and are looking for more information, or could not attend but are interested in the topic, we highly recommend checking his content for valuable advice to make the process decreasingly complicated. 

Read Nico Schoenteich blog post here 

SAP Integration Suite: guide to secure you integrations and compliance best practices  

Our SAP Community member Praveen Kumar Beera, beyond attending SAP TechEd 2025, also made sure to share more important tips on SAP Integration Suite. In his latest blog post, Praveen dives into how to implement and manage access policies effectively, focusing on the importance of securing your integrations and maintaining robust governance. His step-by-step guide has all the images, examples, and links that you need to understand how to archive a better security setup and reduce risks.  

Read Praveen kumar Beera blog post here 

SAP TechEd on Tour: Sessions using SAP Mobile Start 

SAP Mobile Start is the native entry point to the SAP Business Suite, providing access to native or web-responsive business apps along with other content and critical business information. At SAP TechEd in Berlin and Bengaluru, SAPÂ´s â€¯Thilo Berndt and Thomas Bruckner, covered various mobile topics at workshops called "CA260â€¯â€“ Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start". In Thomasâ€™ latest blog post, he shared a full recap with the main technical aspects and valuable material for introduction, building and deploying the base version of the extension, app integration, and extensions, plus the implementation of custom push notifications. The on-site sessions were centered on the ease of building pro-code extensions using SAP Build and specifically SAP Build Code with theâ€¯SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). And if you could not take part and want to have a chance to try it out, they also uploaded all the material and exercises on GitHub within the repository â€¯SAP-samples/teched2025-CA260.â€¯ 

Read Thomas Bruckner blog post here 

Everything you need to know to start with SAP Business Data Cloud 

At SAP TechEd in Sydney, SAPÂ´s Klaus-Peter Sauer presented great sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud, bringing an insightful overview and focusing on growing solutions to the product road map. In case you had the opportunity to watch the session or could not be present but are looking for more information about the topic, recently one of our SAP community members Akhila Unnithan, published a great BDC Beginner Guide. Akhila shared the main key points to understand how the unified data platform works and how it can turn into the only source that provides everyone with a consistent and governed layer of data, whether it is for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications.â€¯She also explains what the existing SAP solutions are that form the foundation (SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP BW or BW/4HANA) and what the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud are (SAP Databricks and SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services). 

Read Akhila Unnithan blog post here 

SAP Community at SAP TechEd on Tour  

SAP TechEd in Berlin: recap by SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi 

â€œSuperheroes without capesâ€œ was the best term the SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi could use to describe our incredible SAP Community team. In her SAP TechEd in Berlin recap blog post, she walks through how the event was one to remember, starting with the fact that she was one of the rewarded SAP Champions who won the SAP TechEd ticket! With amazing pictures to illustrate the moments at the Developers Keynote and Community Clubhouse, Patrizia explains how she was impacted by the outgrowing Joule Agents and SAP Build, for tangible and smart automations directly from the development environment. Therefore, for her, the biggest spark is the fact that AI is no longer an experiment. Patrizia left the event feeling more inspired than ever, and honestly this is the feeling we wish for every single member of our SAP community.  

SAP TechEd in Sydney: connecting before and after 

For a lot of our SAP community members, the in-person connection is the biggest highlight of the SAP TechEd events. And in Sydney, beyond the experience of networking at the Community Theatre, the local community made sure to show up also for the pre-event Sydney Stammtisch. Organized by Mike Doyle and Jeff T., the meeting had around 70-80 attendees and plenty of insightful and honest conversations. It was also an incredible opportunity for our SAP Community Advocates, like Anne Petteroe and Josh Bentley, to finally meet in person many local group members and strengthen even more the connections that were once created online. If you attended and want to share your pictures, comment on Mike latest blog post and share with the community!   

SAP TechEd in Bengaluru: the most energetic and positive crowd  

â€œThe energy, insightful conversations, and knowledge-sharing reaffirmed why this community is so specialâ€œ was our SAP Mentor Mohit Bansal description of his participation at the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru, and we also believe that this is the best way to put it. Just like past events, Bengaluru is always a place full of good and high-energy people, who are always seeking more innovation, more outcomes, and more real-life connections. Some of our amazing SAP Champions and Mentors could present great sessions and bring their expertise on-site, creating one of the best atmospheres for learning with purpose. One of the main key takeaways for many participants was the accelerating adoption of Business AI worldwide, but also how the complexities of this implementation can only be conquered with the support of all our community. We would like to highly recommend that everyone who was present share more of your experience in a blog post or, in case you are a member of the local community, bring your experience details and pictures at the Bengaluru Location group posts. 

News and Events 

ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville 

Recently one of our biggest events in the United States took place in Louisville, Kentucky, and brought light to many AI improvements for developers and businesses, the constant growth of ABAP, Clean Core for digital transformation, and many other SAP topics.  SAPÂ´s Peter Spielvogel, wrote an amazing recap (blog post here) with the details of each one of his many Key Notes. But at ASUG Tech Connect, it was also an opportunity for the local community to come together, bring together ideas, and reflect on the importance of always remembering that people can grow from technological changes. Inspired by the sessions, Peter brought the question in his blog post: â€How can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issuesâ€, and we also believe that all these are mandatory self-reflecting questions. Did you take part? Do you have any other great thoughts about it? Share with us! 

SAP Webinar Open Source: Efficient Microservices Delivery with Project Konfidence 

This week, on December 4th, the SAP Open Source team is hosting another incredible webinar. This edition will be focused on Project Konfidence, a new open source that transforms the delivery of microservice-based SaaS applications. The discussion will be held by Sarah MÃ¼ller, engineering manager and Konfidence project lead at SAP, and Timon SchÃ¼le, head of a software delivery framework at SAP, and hosted by Ulrike Fempel, SAP Open Source Program Office. Make sure to watch out for the time according to your time zone: 3 pm CET, 9 am EST and 7h30 pm IST.  Registration link for the event is here and more details about the event on the blog post here.  

Hobbies Series: Long-distance hiking 

We love to see that even with a month full of work like November was for most of us, our community members are still seeking life balance and taking their time for their passions. The SAP Community Hobbies Series, started by Moshe Naveh, inspired SAPÂ´s Jan Rumig to share more about his love for hiking over thousands of kilometers. In his latest blog post, he explains that everything began with a family tradition that later became more intense, as he started spending two weeks exploring mountain regions. Illustrating with iconic pictures of his adventures in Portugal, New Zeeland, and Germany, for Jan the most wonderful feeling is when he reaches the final signpost after a long trail. If you are interested in starting to hike, we believe this content will give you the right motivation!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite â€“ Cloud integration Message Usage analytics details
entry.content:
Introduction

We are excited to share the latest improvements in SAP Integration Suite designed to support key business scenarios related to consumption-based usage tracking.

With these enhancements, users can now gain deeper insights into message consumption across their integration flows and easily download consolidated monthly usage reports.

Before we dive in, you can refer to the definitions of Instance and Message in Integration Suite here:

  • Tenant definition
  • Message definition

 

How to check Cloud Integration capability consumptions as a Subaccount Admin

If you are a subaccount admin and want to know the consumption of the cloud integration capability in Integration Suite service, follow these steps:

  1. Open your subaccount where Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service is activated.
  2. In the left navigation pane, click on Usage Analytics. This page displays the consumption details for all services.
  3. You can select a date range (Period) to view usage for a specific timeframe.
  4. After selecting the required period, the table will show detailed consumption for all services. In the table, check the â€œService Planâ€ column for entries related to Integration Suite â€“ messages.
  5. For Cloud Integration (CPI) messages, two entries are important:
    1. Total Cloud Integration Messages (e.g., 658 messages)
    2. Excluded Cloud Integration Messages (Only SAP to SAP) (e.g., 320 messages)
  6. Total Cloud Integration (CPI) Chargeable Messages = Total Cloud Integration Messages - Excluded Cloud Integration Messages.

 

 

In case we want to cross-verify this data at each integration flow level/MPL level, we need to navigate to the Messages Usage tile and follow the below steps:

  1. Ensure your user has the required role (PI_Administrator).
  2. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions under the Services tab.
  3. Click Go to Application.
  4. Open the Monitoring tab and select Integrations and APIs.
  5. Scroll down to find the Messages Usage tile and click it.

On initial load, it will show the data for the current month.

 

 

Background

As many of you know, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite already provides double-click metering details for every integration flow execution.

Based on valuable feedback from our customers, this detailed view has proven useful in:

  • Troubleshooting message volume spikes
  • Identifying specific integration flow that contributes the most in message consumption
  • Understanding how key components (such as Splitter, Retry, or SAP-to-SAP Original Content) impact billable messages

These details are crucial for transparency and cost management, as outlined in the message definition documentation.

 

Whatâ€™s New

Many customers expressed the need for a monthly consolidated Excel report for each integration flow â€” including package-level information.
With this new enhancement, users can now:

  • View consolidated monthly message consumption per integration flow and per package
  • Download the report directly from the Message Usage tile in a single click
  • Share usage data easily with Lines of Business (LoBs) for further analysis and discussions

 

Access the Message Usage tile explained above.

  1. Default view shows the current month.

When you open the Message Usage tile, the dashboard automatically loads data for the current month, giving you an immediate overview of your latest message consumption trends.

  1. New Enhancement â€“ Below the chart you will see the consolidated table

This enhanced table provides:

  • Each integration flowâ€™s total message count, including SAP-to-SAP messages
  • The package name associated with each integration flow
    This consolidated view helps you quickly understand usage distribution across packages and identify high-volume integrations.
  1. Download the monthly consolidated report

Simply click the Download button to export the full current monthly report.

 

 

 

Now try to get the previous monthâ€™s data

We provide up to 1 year of historical data. To get the previous monthâ€™s details, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the previous monthâ€™s first and last date

Use the Select Date Range option and choose the start and end dates of the month you want to retrieve.

  1. View the refreshed consolidated table

Once the date range is applied, the table below will automatically refresh, showing the consolidated message usage for the selected month.

  1. Download the monthly consolidated data

Click the Download button to export the full monthâ€™s report.
This file can be used for internal reviews, consumption analysis, or cost-related discussions with business teams.

 

 

Advanced Settings for Better Table Control

Along with the consolidated table, we also provide an Advanced Settings option.
Using this feature, you can:

  • Sort the data based on column
  • Filter records to focus on specific integration flows or packages
  • Adjust or reorder columns to view the information in the format that best suits your analysis

These options give you more flexibility to analyse message consumption in .

 

 

Enhanced Troubleshooting

This new capability extends our existing metering feature, which already helps users:

  • Investigate message spikes
  • Drill down into detailed metering data for specific integration flows
  • Use the interactive charts to visualize data based on selected metrics

Now, with the consolidated reporting feature, you get both detailed troubleshooting views and high-level monthly summaries â€” in one place.

Conclusion

Your feedback has been helpful in shaping these improvements â€” and weâ€™d love to hear more!
Please share your thoughts, experiences, or suggestions for additional insights youâ€™d like to see in Cloud Integration Capability.
